characters: LET'S HEAR IT FOR THE SPACE
BACK AT LUKE AND BRIE- LATER 13

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The following conversation takes place over BLACK or CRED

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Hey Brie?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: It's Luke.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Hi Luke.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Um, I'm actually putting away some groceries I just got.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: What'd you get?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Um. Are you serious, do you want me to tell you?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: No, I guess not. Unless it's, like, a ton of cat food and you don’t have a cat.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Actually I have fifteen cats.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Well, that's weird.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Now you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, did you still want to hang out tonight?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I have to meet up with some friends later on so do you mind if we meet kind of early?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Sure, what time were you thinking?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Do you want to meet at seven?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I'm just kidding, seven is fine.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Is that enough time for you to get ready? I'm sure that bed head takes at least thirty minutes to get into place.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: So this is how it's gonna be, is it? Brie laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: You scared? You want to call the whole thing off?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: No, no. So I'll see you at seven at The Scene, right?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Sounds good.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Okay. See you there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Bye.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A series of shots show the areas of L.A. County winding d from a hard days work. It’s a typical, beautiful evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUKE PUTNAM (25) drives down Santa Monica Blvd. listening music. He checks his reflection one more time in the rear view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke drives by the bar slowly, looking out the window for sign of Brie outside. None.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke walks up to the front of the bar and looks around. After a minute of looking he pulls out his phone and dial number.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Colin. Hey.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey Luke, what’s up?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Not much.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Are you on your date?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Actually, I’m waiting outside. We're supposed to meet at seven. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’m just calling because I felt like a tool just standing here waiting for her.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Right. Understood. Isn’t seven a little early?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I thought so. She said she wanted to get together early because she has to meet up with her friends later. I don’t know if maybe she was giving herself an out just in case or if it’s true, but I said whatever.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Definitely sounds like an out.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Hopefully she won't use it. Luke turns and looks around again.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What’s her name again?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Brie, like the cheese. And actually, I think I see her car.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh, okay.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Wait. Just hang on the line a second.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay. Luke tries to look in the door as someone leaves.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm watching this video on YouTube and.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Alright, I’1l talk to you later man.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay, have fun.  Luke closes the flap on his phone bouncer.

dialogues.speaker: BOUNCER
dialogues.text: Got your I.D.?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Luke pulls out his wallet and I.D. Bouncer.

dialogues.speaker: BOUNCER
dialogues.text: Alright man, have fun.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and heads over to the and shows it to the Luke walks into the bar and sees Brie sitting at a corner table with three guys. One of them is SCOTT (28), who tur and looks behind him. Luke points at him and his expression reads “You?” Scott acknowledges and turns to Brie. scott This is the guy you’re waiting for?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Luke gets to the table and extends a hand to shake.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: What’s up Scott?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: You know him?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah. sScoTtT We worked together.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Where? At our office?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, Scott’s one of the editors.  One of the other guys at the table, JOSH (30) chimes in.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: What’s going on? scoTtT Sit down, sit down.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Uh, I’m gonna get a drink. You- Luke points at Brie but realizes she has a drink in front her.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -are good. Okay. I’11 be back. Luke heads over to the bar. sScoTtT That's really weird.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I work at the reception desk. scoTtT Really? Which floor? I’ve never seen you.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Look harder buddy. I’m there.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BAR
dialogues.text: The bartender is in the middle of telling Luke that they’ out of the beer he wants.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: No, we don’t have it.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Really? Okay, can I get a Coors Light? The bartender pours a draft while Luke looks around some more.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: That’s four. Luke hands him a debit card. BARTENDER (CONT’D) You want to start a tab?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, please. Luke grabs his drink and heads off.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE TABLE
dialogues.text: Luke makes his way over to sit next to Brie, which puts h slightly and awkwardly out of the circle of conversation. Scott turns to him. scoTtT Hey sorry, this is Josh and this is Darrell. Josh and Darrell both give nods or small waves.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Hey, what’s up? Brie turns to Luke and finally exchanges a personal greet

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Hi. How’s it going?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: What are you drinking?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: A little whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Nice.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: How about you?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Uh, Coors Light. The Silver Bullet.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Fancy.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah. So you don’t know these guys?  Suddenly Luke notices that no one at the table has been talking. It’s just him and Brie while the rest of the guy sit, arms folded, small smiles on their faces.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: No, I just said hello while I was waiting for you. Isn’t that weird?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I got here a little early and I didn’t want to do that thing where you just get out your cell phone and talk to someone so you don’t look stupid so I just came in to get a drink and said hello.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Wow. Scott angles back in. sScoTtT So, Darrell here is getting married.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Congratulations! That’s great.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Is it?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Of course it is.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: Thanks. sScoTtT We're trying to talk him out of it. He’s only been dating her for three months.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don’t listen to them.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Three months! It’s like, a season. scoTtT (to Brie mostly) You want to know why I think he’s getting married? Luke takes a sip of beer.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: It’s not true.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It is. sScoTtT It’s because he’s going bald.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: Why would you tell them that? sScoTtT That's why he’s wearing that cap.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: So what if he’s going bald? sScoTtT Because he’s worried that when he goes bald he’s not going to be able to land any other girls.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: It’s not true.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (a la “Seinfeld”) He’s BALD! sScoTtT Take off your hat.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: There’s plenty of bald guys that get laid.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Not with hot girls.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I’m sure I’ve seen some bald guys with attractive girls. sScoTtT Would you date a bald guy?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Me? I don’t know. scoTtT (answering for her) No.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Maybe! It depends!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Look, flowing locks is the not the only quality I look for in a man but I mean, I prefer hair. I can admit that. sScoTtT Everybody prefers hair.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: But true love is hair-blind. sScoTtT Hair-blind?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. sScoTtT But you gotta get the girl to fall in love with you first and that’s much harder to do if you're bald.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I think you are underestimating most girls.  11.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Girls are stupid. Brie bristles visibly.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: What? Brie’s stare is cold as ice. Darrell and Scott pick up on but Josh doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: Look, this is one big conversation that doesn’t need to be happening because I’m not going bald.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: (not budging) Why are girls stupid? sScoTtT Josh is stupid, don’t worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I’m just saying. Luke touches the sleeve of Brie’s jacket.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I like this jacket.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Thanks. Brie barely registers the compliment. Instead her whole demeanor changes and she slouches back into her seat. sScoTtT Dude Luke, you bailed just in time. The office is getting insane.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Really? sScoTtT Mark just started losing his mind for no apparent reason and the work load has totally doubled.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: That sucks.  12. sScoTtT Have you found a new job yet?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Nope. Not really looking for one. scoTtT Nice. Living the dream.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I was an assistant. Like an intern at his office.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (to Brie) And you work there too?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Crazy.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: Hey. Hey. I’m sorry I forgot your name.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Brie.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: Sorry. Brie, like the cheese. I’1ll remember that.. Let me ask you something.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Dude wait. You know who else is named after cheese and is amazing?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Monterey Jack from Chip ‘n’ Dale Rescue Rangers. Scott laughs.  13.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right?! Whenever he smelled cheese he would just start floating toward it like a zeppelin. Amazing.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: A zeppelin?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: Dude stop, I have a serious question.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Okay. . .

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: I’m getting married in four months and we have a date set and everything. And so now my fiancee wants to stop having sex from now until the wedding so it can feel kind of like having sex for the first time again on the wedding night.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: Isn't that stupid?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: That’s the question?

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: I mean, is this a female thing? Am I crazy or does it not make any sense?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. It doesn’t make sense to me, but if she feels strongly about it and it makes sense to her then you should probably just do it.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: We had sex on the first night we met.  scoTtT He tells this to everyone when he first meets them.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: So it’s like, what’s the point?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Like I said, I don’t know. I gave a guy a handjob at an assembly in ninth grade but some people are just weird about sex. Luke’s eyes visibly widen as he takes a big sip of beer.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: She probably just feels guilty. Is she religious or her parents, are they really religious?

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: Not really. sScoTtT Wait, so could other kids see you giving him the handjob in the assembly?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: No, he put his backpack on his lap or something. It was discreet.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Dude, tell them what happened.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: What happened what?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: When you met her parents.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: No. Stop interrupting! Scott bursts out laughing. Luke and Brie are lost. scoTtT It’s brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Tell the fucking story!

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I'm telling it.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: God damn you guys. Scott continues laughing. Luke is almost done with his beer.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: So Darrell went and spent the weekend with his girlfriend's parents last week. They live in Michigan.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Is this an embarrassing meet the parents story? sScoTtT Big time.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: He was in Michigan and his girlfriend's parents took everyone out for an engagement party kind of deal and this guy gets hammered. Just fucking stone cold drunk.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: Everybody was buying me shots.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: So they go back to the house late that night and him and his girlfriend try to have sex.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: What? What do you mean try?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You said you fell asleep like three minutes into it. scott Three minutes into it is two minutes after it’s over.  16.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: Yeah, I fell asleep but we had sex for a little bit first.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Whatever, so they fall asleep naked and he wakes up at like 4 am feeling like he’s gonna barf.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: It was inevitable.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: He stumbles to the bathroom, still naked and pukes like six times.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: This story is fucking gross so far.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Hang on, hang on. So, he finishes up and stumbles back into the bedroom, climbs back into bed and falls asleep. It’s not until the next morning does anybody realize that he had gone back into the wrong room and climbed naked into bed with his girlfriend’s brother.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: My future brother-in-law. Brie laughs. Scott is cracking up too.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: That’s not true.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It’s totally fucking true.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: That kind of shit doesn’t happen to people.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: I wish it didn’t but it did. sScoTtT Amazing.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Was he mad?  17.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: He took it pretty well. He was cool. It wasn’t as damaging as it could have been.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: I know, I know. Believe me, I thought that stuff only happened in John Hughes movies, but no.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: John Hughes?

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: Yeah, there’s a scene like that in Planes, Trains and Automobiles.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I haven't seen it.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: “Those aren’t pillows!”

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: It’s good. Luke is finished with his beer and sees a break in the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Brie) You want another drink? Brie looks at her drink- just a few sips left.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Actually, I should probably get going to meet my friends. Luke looks a little frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.  18. sScoTtT The best part of that movie is when John Candy turns into the devil for like three seconds when they are stuck in between the two trucks. Like, for no reason, he has a devil costume on for three seconds and he’s screaming.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: (to Luke) I’m gonna have a cigarette though, do you want one?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Uh, sure.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke and Brie stand outside the bar on the corner. Brie pulls a pack of American Spirits out of her purse and han one to Luke. He twiddles it around his fingers while she pulls one out herself.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Hang on. Brie approaches a SMOKER standing next to them. BRIE (CONT’D) Excuse me, do you have a light?

dialogues.speaker: SMOKER
dialogues.text: Yeah. Smoker pulls a Zippo out of his pocket and lights it for Brie. She dangles her cigarette in and takes a puff.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Thanks. Brie comes back over to Luke and offers him her smoke.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here.  19.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Thanks. How come you have cigarettes but no lighter?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: It’s a way of trying to quit. Cut down at least.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Does it work?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Does it look like it’s working? Luke lights his cigarette with hers and hands it back.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: So you gotta go huh?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I think so. My friends are kind of waiting for me.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: That’s cool.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you know those guys.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I don’t know all those guys, just Scott. We just worked together. But now we don’t.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: So, this was your first week of unemployment, right?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m on day three.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: But you’ve got a plan.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I’m working on a piece that I pitched to the Times.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: The New York Times? Jesus. You didn’t tell me that.  20.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: The L.A. Times.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Oh. That’s cool too.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Well, they have this kind of long- winded editorial process so I’m getting bounced around a little bit. But they’re giving me time, which is nice.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: That is nice of them. You've got enough money to make it last?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: That’s the plan. I took out a loan from the bank. (beat) I figure it’s like going back to school but I get to spend the money the way I want.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: That's pretty smart. How much did you get?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: They gave me a loan for five thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: That’s it?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I’m eating sandwiches. Brie raises her eyebrows.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I would have asked for ten. If you’re gonna go, go all the way.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Well I’m just more frugal than you are.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Or less daring.  21.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I always thought it would be funny to do a spoof show of “The Fraggles”, you know that show?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: But have it be “The Frugals” instead and it’s just a bunch of tight wad investors and bankers living underground being like “You spent how much on socks!?” Brie chuckles. Luke is pleased. They take a drag.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How about you? How’ve you been?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Uh, fine. Work is boring and stressful.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah but that building would collapse if you weren't there.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Ha, right. And that’s the only reason I’m still there. To hold that building up.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Well, what else would you be doing?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I mean, I don’t know. I guess I can’t complain. It’s a safe job and I’m making money. The money’s not the problem, you know?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, totally.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, for Christmas last year I bought my mom her first pair of really expensive shoes. Not her first pair- you know.  22.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: How expensive?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Just- expensive. They don’t have them where she lives. I don’t even think she knew they existed. I mean, she used to be this fashion maven but she’s starting to lag a bit in her old age. So, I gotta pick up her slack.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I know what you mean. I won a game show and-

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Wait, you won a game show?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: You haven't heard of it.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Nobody's heard of it.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Come on, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: It’s called On the Cover.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: What the hell is On the Cover?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: See?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: What is it?  23.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: It’s just. They show you a fake magazine cover of like, People Magazine with Denzel Washington's picture on it and you have to name who’s “on the cover”.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: That’s it?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Sounds easy.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: And retarded.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Have you ever done it? It’s tough getting that buzzer to work before anyone else's.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. I’m sorry. But you won, right?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: How much money?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Ten thousand bucks.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Ten thousand bucks!? For a little game show no one has heard of?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, so that Christmas was the first time I could ever afford to get everyone in my family cool presents.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ.  24.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I’m usually the guy that gives everyone a CD or a book, but I actually got some cool gifts that year.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Loans and game shows, no wonder you don’t need a job.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: How much do you have left?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Why, you gonna order more expensive drinks?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: None.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Really, none. I bought a car. Not a new one or anything. A used one, but I bought it straight up. Caaash.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: So you're broke again?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Broke is a strong word. No, I got the loan. I got some savings. And I have a car.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I could totally win that show.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I don’t know if it’s still on the air. They pause and smoke their cigarettes.  25.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I’d do really well at Jeopardy. It’s all proper names and places and one or two-word responses and I’m good at that stuff.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Okay, what's the capitol of Cyprus?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Cyprus? Greece?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Nicosia.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Look it up. I remember it because it’s spelled close to Nicoise salad. Mnemonically.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I’m impressed. Most people something about Cyprus on the news and think it’s like, a made-up country.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: But Jeopardy. Or Presidents! I know a shit-ton about presidents. Half the stuff on Jeopardy is presidential facts, so I wouldn't even have to study that. Luke smokes, doesn’t really inhale. Brie catches this, bu says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'd win and I'd use the money to buy my mom a house. A beach house. Out near Rockport or somewhere maybe a little less uppity.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Moms love beach houses.  26.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: It was really nice getting a solid gift for my mother. Even if it was just shoes.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: What did your dad get?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Dad got a tie. It’s what he likes.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: My mom asked me to make her a mix last year. She wanted to know what I was listening to. I put some songs on a CD for her and gave it to her. I made her a mixtape. I put “2 Minutes to Midnight” by Iron Maiden as a hidden bonus track at the end and she wasn’t nearly as amused about that as I was.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know that one.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: (sings but trails off mid- way ) “2 Minutes to Midnight!!!!" Brie nods and looks around. A girl clacks outside on her heels. She pulls up next to Brie. Her name is STACY and she talks loudly into her cel phone.

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: I don’t care what he eats. It bores me. (beat) Did she hit you? Did she hit him? Brie and Luke listen as Brie finishes her cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: STACY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter that he’s from South America. People aren’t any different down there. They follow the same rules as the rest of the world. (beat) There’s meat. And then there’s grass.  27. Luke catches Brie’s eye. He makes a face. She makes one b

dialogues.speaker: STACY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And that’s what you’ve gotta tell them. (beat) Hold on a second. (turns to Brie; sotto voce) Can I have one of those, I’m so sorry? Brie, smiling, hands one over.

dialogues.speaker: STACY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you. (back into phone) No, I’m sorry, I was talking to someone. Brie steps her cigarette out. She notices Luke has almost half of his left.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Slow smoker.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Savor it, that’s what I say.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: You don’t smoke do you? Luke inhales a drag and blows the smoke out confidently, if that answers the question.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Sometimes. They look around at the few other people standing outside few feet away stand a GUY and a GIRL seemingly not very h with each other. The guy holds his phone out and is texting away. The girl looks at him with disgust. After a moment and in one fell swoop she SWATS the phone of his hands and it BOUNCES on the concrete.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! Luke and Brie look at each other with wide eyes.  28.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yikes.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I think there’s gonna be a fight.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I think so too. They look again but the couple have wandered off up the street.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you ever been in a fight?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: No. Have you?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah. In eighth grade. Everybody was picking fights and it was like, the cool thing. So I picked the smallest, weakest guy in the class and I made him fight me.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: What a jerk!

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I know. His name was Dawson Mullen and he was from Canada.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Poor Dawson Mullen. Brie gets out another cigarette to smoke.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Our high school was right next to this movie theatre called the Bijou. When you wanted to pick a fight with someone, you went up to them and said ‘Bijou parking lot. Two Thirty.’

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: That was the call out? Still listening, Brie bums another light off of someone.  29.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah. The thrown gauntlet. Bijou parking lot was where all the real shit went down. Pot smoking. All that.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I guess my friend Lauren’s house would be our Bijou parking lot equivalent because that’s where we always did the bad stuff.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: So. There were a bunch of kids all waiting on the grassy side of this movie theatre. And they form this big circle and we get in the middle. And Dawson is like “Come on, start something. Start something.” So I pushed him and he just clocks me in the face. Out of nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Ha!

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I didn’t fall over or anything but man, it hurt. And I guess normal people get angry when they get punched in the face but I just kind of realized that fighting was dumb.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Aww, poor little pacifist.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: He sort of knocked some sense into me. So, that was the end of the fight.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: You lost in one punch?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I forfeited.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I kind of had a fight once. This girl was really pissing me off in tenth grade. She thought I was flirting with her boyfriend or something, which I probably was. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BRIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But she tried to start something in the cafeteria. And she was Puerto Rican so the whole lunch room split into whites versus Puerto Ricans for the fight that never actually happened. It was like the Jets versus the Sharks.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: West Side Story reference. Don’t worry if you don’t get it, I’m the nerd, not you.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I was in West Side Story.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Really? Who’d you play?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: (thinks) Like, Jet Boy number four. Brie laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: That’s hilarious.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I remember we had to give ourselves names on these character sheets, to make you feel like you were really “acting.” And so I turned mine in with the name “Davey”. But my friends all turned in these cool names like “Action” and “One Punch”. And I was stuck with “Davey”.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I had to do the same thing when I was a pink lady in “Grease”. We had those sheets too. You had to fill in all this unnecessary information like what our favorite ice cream flavor and stuff was. So dumb.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Can I have another one of those?  31. Brie hands Luke another cigarette and he lights it with h

dialogues.speaker: LUKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My high school did this Shakespeare play called “The Merry Wives of Windsor”. I wasn’t in it but I saw it, and there’s a scene where two guys are talking to each other. And they’re talking about something, but I guess they forget their lines because there’s just this sudden silence: like, fifteen seconds of nothing. Then one guy turns to the other and says “So, how ‘bout the Bulls?”

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Swear to God. And this is during the playoffs, so the other guy’s like: “Repeat the three-peat!” So they talk about the Bulls for a good two minutes. I guess someone was supposed to enter and they didn’t or something, but then the three-peat guy just got up and started doing the worm.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: The audience loved it. They all cheered when he did the worm. In the middle of “The Merry Wives of Windsor”.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: That’s hilarious.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: That’s Tennessee.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I saw a production of “West Side Story” that was like, the traveling Broadway production. And you know how in the end, Chino is supposed to run out on stage with the gun and shoot Tony?  32.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Well I guess the guy playing Chino forgot the gun because he runs out on the stage. Pauses for a second. Then takes off his shoe and yells “Poison boot!” and throws it at Tony. Luke laughs. BRIE (CONT’D) And it hits him in the chest and he just looks at it for a second and then falls over.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Poison boot?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Best improv ever. But the best part is that the scene has to continue and Maria has to pick up the shoe and be like “How much poison is left in this boot, Chino? Enough for you? Enough for me?”

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: That’s worse than the worm.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Way worse.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Do you still do any theater?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: No. I got over that.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, me too. My swansong was the Head Flying Monkey in “The Wiz”.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: “The Wizard of Oz"?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: No, no. “The Wiz”.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Really?  33.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Public school’s are all about color blind casting. We had white people trying to sing soul in “The Wiz”, we did “The Sound of Music” with three white and two Filipino Von Trapp kids. And we even had black Nazis in “The Sound of Music”.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Jesus. I haven’t thought about this stuff in a long time. It is absurd.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I love it. I love High School stuff. They are finished with their cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want to go back inside?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah. They turn to head back into the bar and are met at the doorway by Scott, Darrell and Josh heading out. scoTtrT Hey, we're heading to that other bar if you guys want to come.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Umm. I think we’re gonna hang out here a bit more. sScoTtT Okay. Come to Saddle Ranch on Sunset if you change your mind.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Okay. See you.

dialogues.speaker: DARRELL
dialogues.text: Nice meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke stands at the bar ordering two more drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun has set and the night takes over the city. It’s a cool, calm evening all across Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brie and Luke stand by the wall of the bar, drinking and talking.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: You work with kids, right?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I do. I work with middle and elementary school kids. Volunteer work, mostly.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I didn’t know you were a teacher.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: We do mostly after school stuff and there’s workshops that we have during the day. Kids from all these schools around Venice take field trips to come see us, so they’re usually pretty happy to be somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: What do you work-shop with ten year- olds?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Well, one of them, my favorite actually, is a storytelling workshop. They come in and the idea is to get them to write a story as a group. I help them through. This is pretty fun, actually. We have a computer that projects up onto the wall so you can see what’s being typed.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Sounds like a big operation.  35.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: It's pretty big. It’s me and five other people. Got a typist, an illustrator who draws on this pad that’s connected to another computer, but here’s the best part. There’s a cranky editor named Mr. Crabtree who lives in the attic, and occasionally he'll come in over this intercom. He’s like: “Where's my stories! I'm trying to run a publishing company here! I need fifteen stories by twelve o'clock or Brie's going to lose her job!"

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: The kids respond to pressure like that?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s just another one of the volunteers in the office talking in a grumpy voice through a baby monitor. They get a kick out of it. They kind of freeze up, but then after awhile, after the editor comes back on and yells at them a little bit more, they get wise. They usually spend most of the workshop trying to figure out which one of us is the voice from the attic.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: And what exactly do you do?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: They come in and I ‘conduct’ them. All on the floor sitting in a circle, like fourteen or eighteen kids. I ask them, what’s the first thing you need to write a story? Luke waits. Brie nods at him to answer the question.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Oh, a title.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: No. The title comes last. You can’t get married to a title early on.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: A main character?  36.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Exactly. I ask them what their favorite animal is, and we usually go from there. Sometimes it’s pirates or astronauts, but animals always do well in a pinch.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: You've gotta make sure there’s a boy and a girl, right?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Gotta have both. If there’s more girls in the class, the main character becomes a girl squid or a girl construction worker. Same thing if it’s more boys.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: How long does it take.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Two hours. We all write the story together and then the kids have to go and finish up their specific end to the story.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: So you get fifteen stories with all different endings?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: For the most part. You'd be surprised how many of their endings are the same. We try to push them to be more inventive, but the kids are of the same mind about things, without even knowing it.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: So they all end with the girl squid and the boy pirate living happily ever after?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: You got a better ending?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: No. I wish those two all the best. They deserve it. The conversation lulls. Different CHARACTERS from the bar take over.  11 37. ADAM and MARINA are talking at a table.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Delilah.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: That’s a great middle name.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: I love it. I’m going to name my daughter Delilah.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: Did you grow up religious?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Hunh? No.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: You know there’s major religious overtones with a name like that.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: Samson and Delilah? You don’t know that story? She’s the one who cut off all his hair when he was asleep.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: She did what?

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: Samson was the strongest man in the city. And Delilah cut off his hair with a pair of golden scissors. She took his strength by cutting off his hair.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: What book is that from? Adam is incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: The bible?

dialogues.speaker: AT ANOTHER SPOT 11
dialogues.text: CHAS and DAPHNE sit at a table. Chas is wasted and scribb on a bar napkin.  12 38.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Fifteen to ten! Daphne sips at her drink. Looks horrified.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's only five more points! Daphne gets up, puts a napkin over her drink, and exits frame. Chas sits alone. Eventually, he will go to the bathroom and insult Luke’s penis.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER SPOT 12
dialogues.text: LEMUEL and NAN talking about the tissue bank she works at

dialogues.speaker: LEMUEL
dialogues.text: You got a prostate?

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: Yesterday. A piece of one.

dialogues.speaker: LEMUEL
dialogues.text: Is it like hamburger?

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: It’s not cooked.

dialogues.speaker: LEMUEL
dialogues.text: What’s it like though? How big is it?

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: Looks like...fibrous...I think it had a tumor. It was hard.

dialogues.speaker: LEMUEL
dialogues.text: You touched it?

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: One was a tumor and one wasn’t. With the forceps.

dialogues.speaker: LEMUEL
dialogues.text: Poke me where you think it feels like. Nan pokes his arm in a couple of places.

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: Kind a like that. Lemuel pokes his own arm.  13 39. (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raw steak. Kind of. Maybe like a chicken steak.

dialogues.speaker: LEMUEL
dialogues.text: You're not a vegetarian, are you?

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: Most of the time. No cows.

dialogues.speaker: BACK AT LUKE AND BRIE- LATER 13
dialogues.text: Still sitting, Brie unloads her purse onto the table. She produces a phone from deep inside its guts.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: We should call Leslie. Luke holds a hand over his right eye like an eye-patch.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Leslie? Brie punches him.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Because she’s on a first date.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Oh really?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, she’s on a date with Average Man. Have you met him?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: He’s on the fifth floor. He’s a lawyer. He’s nice and everything but he’s totally ordinary so Leslie and I call him Average Man.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: That doesn’t sound very good.  14 40.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: We should see if he becomes Above Average Man on a date.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Okay. Brie gets out her phone and dials. Luke takes a sip of hi beer and looks around.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Hey Leslie. . . How’s your date? . . . Really? I assumed it was gonna be bad since you picked up... That's good. . . Is he buying you average priced drinks? . . . Nice. Luke stretches and works on his beer.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is he right there? . . . Okay, I’1l just ask yes and no questions. . . Does he have man boobs?. . . Can you see them? Brie is amusing herself. BRIE (CONT’D) Has he mentioned his car more than two times already? . . . Are you gonna make him double bag it? Brie looks at Luke but doesn’t make any indication of try to wrap it up. Luke mimes out “I’m going to the bathroom”. Brie nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke walks into the bathroom and up to the only available urinal out of two. Next to him stands CHAS.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Hey. Luke begins to pee.  15 41.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Nice cock.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Just kidding. Chas zips up his pants and leaves the bathroom without washing his hands. Luke stands by himself, peeing. Running through the eveni in his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brie is still talking on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I’m hanging out with Luke. . . He worked for the magazine. . . Yes you do, he’s the “Supplies!” guy. . . I know. . . Yeah, it’s fine. Whatever. Luke comes back and sits down. BRIE (CONT’D) Okay. I’11 talk to you later. Bye. Brie hangs up the phone and puts it back into her purse.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Sure. How is she?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Good. She says Average Man is a gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: That’s good. Is he older?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Not like way older but yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Well, go Average Man, go!  16 talking to each other.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I’m kind of hungry. Are you hungry?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah I could eat.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Where can we go?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: There’s a pizza place nearby. up the street I think.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Is it good?
Just Yeah. I mean, it’s pizza but it’s good.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Pizza sounds amazing.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Let’s do it.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: O-kay.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Brie reaches over and downs the last sip of Luke’s beer. 16 Luke and Brie step outside of the bar to find a small gathering of people out smoking or talking. I’m not exactly sure which way it is. Luke walks over to them.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey man, where is that place? Luke looks around and sees two guys, TALON and SPENCER Talon is holding a TO-GO PIZZA BOX Talon looks up and realizes Luke means the pizza.

dialogues.text: Yeah, I think we’re gonna get a slice.

dialogues.speaker: TALON

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Oh thanks but I think we’re gonna get our own.

dialogues.speaker: TALON

dialogues.text: No thanks. Spencer leans in and adds-

dialogues.speaker: SPENCER
dialogues.text: Dude, we can’t eat it all.

dialogues.speaker: TALON

dialogues.speaker: LUKE

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Thanks. Luke and Brie reach in and grab a slice each. Talon out his free hand.

dialogues.speaker: TALON

dialogues.speaker: BRIE

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Luke. reaches

dialogues.speaker: TALON

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Um, nothing at the moment.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE

dialogues.speaker: BRIE

dialogues.text: Really? Is that nice?

dialogues.speaker: TALON

dialogues.text: I’m terrible.

dialogues.text: Good. I’11 win then. They make their way towards the pool table. Luke puts some money in and racks the pool balls over the following:

dialogues.speaker: BRIE

dialogues.text: Those guys?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Just the way they talked and acted. I don’t know, the demeanor.

dialogues.text: You lived with models?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Mmm hmm. It was what I like to refer to as a ‘quick-change’ atmosphere. It’s like theatre, always changing outfits. Changing zip codes, changing drugs. Changing the people you’re friends with. Everything. You go out to bars in Beverly Hills and all the drinks are paid for. It’s an interesting way to live your life.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Living through the kindness of others.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know if ‘kindness’ is the word I'd use. Luke breaks. He pauses. Considers the table.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: What do you think about that?  47.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: About the fact that men are supposed to buy the drinks? Don’t you think they’re only buying drinks to get you drunk?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: And not for the actual enjoyment of buying someone a drink?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Brie holds up her drink.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Are you trying to get me drunk?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: No, but pizza guys might be.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Listen. That’s the way it is. I don’t mind some churlish guy buying me a couple of vodka sodas. I don’t have to go home with him. There’s no contract I’m aware of. There’s no body promise.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Isn't that patronizing?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I don’t think about people patronizing me. It’s just a social structure. A way of doing things that’s accepted. ‘A’ leads to ‘B.’

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: So ‘A’ is the initial contact?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Sure. Then ‘B’ is the next drink or the conversation or whatever comes next.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: What happens when you get to ‘C’?  48.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Well, if ‘C’ means me taking my shirt off and barreling down on some guy in the middle of the bar...There doesn’t have to be a ‘C’. The ball is in my court.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: What if you make the initial contact? Then by the time it gets to ‘C’, the ball is in their court.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: No. Wrong. When it gets to ‘C’, the ball is never in the guy’s court.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Oh really?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Never. But here’s where the theory fails: Marriage.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Getting married...

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Wait, backtrack a second. How often do you barrel down on some guy in the middle of the bar?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Fuck off. Get your mind out of the gutter. How would you like it if girls were always buying you drinks and staring at your boobs while you tried to have a conversation with them? This startles Luke. He can’t help but glance down at Brie boobs. BRIE (CONT’D) You just looked at my boobs.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I know! You said the word “boobs” and it just happened. Sorry.  49.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Well, see?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I apologize.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Think about every girl you know. What if every relationship you had with a member of the opposite sex was based on the assumption that they would fuck you if they got the chance? Like, every time some guy said he wanted to get a drink with you or go for a walk, that that guy is actually thinking: maybe I'll have a chance with her tonight. Maybe tonight will be the night she gets drunk and wants to fuck me.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: That’s pretty dire.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: It is pretty fucking dire, if you wanna know the truth. But wait: marriage. Have you ever heard about the Coolidge effect?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Calvin Coolidge. Thirtieth president of the United States. 1923 to... (thinks) 1930.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I told you. I’m not fucking around with my presidential knowledge.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Jeopardy’s gonna call you any day.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: But, so. Calvin Coolidge and his wife...Grace...are taking separate tours of a farm somewhere. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BRIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Coolidge is walking along and she sees all these hens hopping around and pecking at things and Mrs. Coolidge says, “Man, that’s a lot of hens. That’s a lot of work for one old rooster.” The tour guide says, “He’s fine, ma’am. The rooster works very hard.” Then Mrs. Coolidge says, “Really? He's working hard every day?” “Oh sure”, says the man. “Dozens of times a day”. “Interesting!” says Mrs. Coolidge. “You be sure to tell that to the President!” Brie catches a breath. BRIE (CONT’D) So later, Coolidge is walking along with the same tour guide and he passes the hens. The tour guide tells him with Mrs. Coolidge said. “Same hen every time?” he asks. “Well, no”, says the guide. “It’s a different one every time.” Coolidge leans in to the guide and smirks and says, “You tell that to Mrs. Coolidge.”

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: There’s a moral to this story.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: There is. And it’s that men are hard-wired to spread their seed as often as possible with as many different partners as possible.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Well, it makes sense, from an evolutionary standpoint.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: No, it’s bullshit! They do these experiments where they put one male rat in a cage with ten female rats and he fucks them all like crazy. But then he gets tired and just sleeps in the corner and the female rats will nudge him and lick him and stuff but he’s just not into it anymore. Until they put a new female in the mix and then all of a sudden he’s horny as hell again.  18 19 20 51.

dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: And they say that’s the Coolidge Effect but really, they’ve done the same thing with female rats and they have the same reaction. It’s not just a male thing. The real moral is everybody gets tired of fucking the same person after a while.
