dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: (nodding) It was magical.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I think I can do that.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Now come meet Dickie.  31 63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the kitchen, DICKIE (20's) is holding court. GIRLS and guy or two stand around him. Brie makes her way through t room with Luke trailing behind her.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: You want to know what the problem is? I stopped reading books. For two weeks now I haven’t read a thing. I haven’t had any time to myself at all. My attention span is fucked. I can’t concentrate, my vocabulary is getting worse... He spots Brie.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey again.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I want you to meet my friend Luke.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: Hey Luke. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You friends with Cameron?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I just met her out front, actually. She was doing cartwheels.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: She should be. You only turn eighteen once, right?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: She's eighteen?

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: No. There would be a lot of people in jail tonight if she was just turning eighteen.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: (raising her hand) I’m one of them.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: (to Luke) Having fun?  64.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I just got here.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I found him on the side of the road. He looked lonely. He told me he was tired from selling his body all the time.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: It’s a tough racket.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Those streets are cold, man. Luke expects a laugh that doesn’t come.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Dickie is the most amazing writer.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE DICKIE
dialogues.text: So I hear. Oh my God...

dialogues.speaker: BRIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No he seriously is. You two would get along. You could talk and talk about books.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: Are you a writer? LUKE’ BRIE Well, right now I’m working Luke is taking time off. He on... just quit his job to work on a piece.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's fantastic. So you’re unemployed?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I’m working on my own stuff right now.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: What? Journalism? Screenplays? Everybody out here seems to be secreting screenplays.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, no. I’m working on a long piece for the Los Angeles Times.  65.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: Oh, do you know Dean Baquet?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: He’s the Editor-In-Chief. Last time I checked. He’s an amazing man. Just came in from New York and took the reins. Amazing man. They treated him like shit in New York.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I don’t know him. I’m working with Karen Middleton in the Sunday section.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: That’s great. One of those big Sunday features.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: That’s what I’m hoping for.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: (to Luke) Do you know Stanford University?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE BRIE
dialogues.text: Sure. I know it. Dickie just finished his fellowship there.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Really? The Graduate Program?

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: The Stegner.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: They paid his whole way for two years. I told you. He’s a brilliant writer.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: (to Brie) Are you trying to hook us up?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I’m just saying!  66.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: (to Luke) It was a cool program. Tobias Wolff. Amazing man.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I love his work. I applied there last year but I guess they weren’t having it.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: Ah. Fuck ‘em. I mean, you know, the competition is so fucking fierce for what? Like twelve places?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I didn’t apply to the Stegner thing. Just for the journalism department.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: Well they’re obviously idiots. Go back to ‘em next year with your Times feature. They’1l be drooling. By that time, you’1ll have done a bunch of work and you won’t even want to bother with school.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: (to Brie and Dickie) How long have you guys known each other?

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: Centuries. What was it? The Boer War?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: We used to be roommates. The House of Clothes.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. What a mess that was. (to Brie) You know I saw Stephanie recently. She made the cover of...Italian Vogue I think? She seemed like she was doing well.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: (to Dickie) So you lived with all those models?  32 67.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: On and off. They were kind enough to give me a couch for awhile and then Stephanie...she’s the successful one...had to go to Milan or something...so I just subletted her room for what turned out to be the better part of like, a year and a half.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I’m so glad I don’t live there anymore.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. It was rough. All those models prancing around in their underwear. Pillow-fighting. I swear. It was like something you read about.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know, it seemed pretty normal at the time.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: Not this one though. (points to Brie) In her room with the door shut and her nose in a book.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Ha. Not always.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: (smiling) Not always. Dickie and Brie both laugh.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Where’s the bathroom around here? Luke slides away to find the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERON finds Luke sitting on the couch, watching people, drinking beer from a red plastic cup.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Putnam.  68.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Hi. Cameron sits down on the couch. She makes whoever was sit down get up.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s my birthday.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I heard. How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: You’re not supposed to ask a lady her age.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: You set me up for it. But if you want to tell somebody your true age, it might as well be me since I don’t know anyone else here.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Guess.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I’m not guessing. That is the road to peril. Cameron leans in to Luke, uncomfortably close. He might s back a bit into the couch.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: You have to guess.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: You have to tell me. (beat) Here. Whisper it into my ear. Cameron whispers something inaudible in Luke’s ear.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She told you that huh? Cameron nods. Luke grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s nice of her.  69.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I’m just kidding. She didn’t say that. You got kind of surly. That’s cute.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Surly is cute?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Have you played beer battleship?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: No, but I saw a bit. I think I might come out there in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: You should. It’s amazing.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: ELSEWHERE
dialogues.text: EDIE and FEROCIOUS stand in a corner. Ferocious is acting out his name on the air guitar.

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: You look retarded when you play air guitar.

dialogues.speaker: FEROCIOUS
dialogues.text: I don’t care. I’m gifted.

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: No. I mean it. I’m going to punch you in the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke and Brie sit outside.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: You can mingle if you want.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: No, I did. It’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: You don’t have to entertain me.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Good, because I left my spinning plates at home.  Pause. 70.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Whenever I go to parties, I usually just wind up talking with the one person I came with.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Everybody does that.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I usually just sit around and watch people. I’m pretty shy, usually.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: You’re not shy. You’re the least shy person I’ve ever met.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: No. I am in certain situations. Parties aren’t really my forte.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Well, Cameron likes you.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: That's cool. My confidence points are increasing.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Maybe if you're lucky, you'll get throw-up on your shoes. Luke They're pretty serious here.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Got a lot of steam to let off.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know this girl who’s a stand-up comedian. Totally frightening, right? She feeds off getting up at open mic nights and telling jokes, but when you get her in a party atmosphere or regular social situations, she’s just terrified.  71.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah. You’re supposed to get outdoors and meet new people, right? So now I have a compulsion to get out of the house and into new situations. Like maybe there’s a whole echelon of people I’m missing out on being with. I think I'd just like to be better socially adjusted.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I was an insomniac, did I tell you that?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Well, I grew up in this really small town called Dracut and I was too young to have my own car or anything and try to make out to Boston or Lowell or wherever and do fun things. And I had the worst time sleeping. The whole house would be asleep and I couldn’t even get up and walk around or anything because I was afraid of waking up my sister. (She actually smiles a little at the following: ) So I'd sit there and stare at the ceiling and imagine all the fun things that were happening without me.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Were you ever popular?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. In High School. And college. I mean, you know. I had friends. But I had a real awkward period first. Do you remember when parties used to be the highlight of your week? Or at least they were something that you looked forward to.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Like a county fair in the summer.  72.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Exactly. They were unique. Maybe because we just hadn’t been to so many. They were still a new experience. You know... (eyebrows raised) .--dancing with boys.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Oh God. I hated dancing. (beat) Agh. See, I’m having flashbacks. Luke holds his hands out like a zombie, except that his h are turned like he’s holding a phantom dancer. Brie smile He puts his arms down.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This may sound stupid, but maybe you can help me out with this thought I’ve been having. I worry sometimes that what I’m experiencing won’t be enough. In the long run. That I’m putting all my money in this one bank...or...no...that I’m reading this one newspaper. And then, one day, come to find out that this newspaper is wrong. That it’s been reporting the wrong news. I’ve been reading about things never really happened. Or that happened slightly different than reported.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: But if you never find out then it’s all real news to you.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: But what happens when the curtain is suddenly pulled back?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Why did you move here?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. It rained a lot in Knoxville. We were in the mountains. When I got out here, it hadn’t rained in six months. I thought: this is the place for me for now. But now I just miss the rain. I miss having the option of bad weather.  Pause. 73.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: That’s it? You moved out here for the sunshine? That’s pretty generic.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: But it’s a good reason. You lived in a small town. You should know. All I ever wanted to do was be somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know about that. But you can’t just move for the sake of moving.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I could do stories all over the world.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Do you worry about what people are thinking about?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Worry how? What people are thinking about me?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I don’t know that it worries me. But I might get upset if some guy was talking shit about my haircut behind my back. Say, if this guy was my best friend. I might find that a little unsettling.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I worry about people’s priorities.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Like what do people really want? I’m a secretary. You’re an intern. Cameron is a bartender. We've all been out of college for a while. Our priorities are becoming more streamlined. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BRIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why isn’t anybody really going after something and putting us all to shame? I mean, aside from Dickie, who is amazing and driven, I don’t think anyone knows what's next.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I feel like I’m going after something.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I mean, I guess we all are. But not really.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Maybe you aren’t, but don’t lump me in with your slacker friends. Brie looks at Luke for a long second.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: You’re twenty-what? Seven? You’re not married. You think you can be single and drift. Write your pieces here and there and do what you want.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: And you can’t?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I can do whatever I goddamn well please. Brie is moving off into her own world. Luke is trying to up, but foundering. He tries to interject when he can, bu never quite manages to get a word in.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: But you’re not the only one.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: (sharply) I know I’m not. I know I’m not the only person on the planet. And I’m sorry for assuming and using you as an example but I think you know what I’m saying.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: But you shouldn’t worry about other people too much. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LUKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s like if you let everyone at the grocery store cut in front of you in line. You’d never get to the cash register.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: No. That’s stupid. It’s not like that. But I see it when I go home and see my sister and my cousins and they're all married and have kids and they look at me like... (beat) ...No. It’s not something that isn’t forced upon me all the time: I’ve watched my little nieces growing up and now they’re like ten years old and playing sports in school. And taking gymnastics. My sister’s taken a completely different path than me. But she’s completely clueless. And it’s just going to get worse as I get older. No one has any idea that doing what you want actually makes you happy in the end.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: That sucks.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Don’t try and sympathize with me. It’s not like it’s something you’1l ever have to deal with.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: (quickly, defensively) I'm just trying to be agreeable.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Well, it’s pretty fucking disagreeable.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I don’t know what to say then. She gets up.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I’m going to get a beer. Luke has nothing to say to this. He moves around in the backyard for a second and spots DARREN talking on the pho  34 76.

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: Hey. What’s going on? (beat) I was wondering, they turned the shower off at my place and I was wondering if I could come over and use yours (beat) It's like twelve-forty... (hopefully: ) I'll bring my own towel. Luke looks around at the other PARTYGOERS. The party is dying down a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke walks through the party and doesn’t see Brie. GEANNIE, a girl, approaches Luke.

dialogues.speaker: GEANNIE
dialogues.text: I know you, man.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah? Geannie grabs her friend, SAMANTHA, and points to Luke.

dialogues.speaker: GEANNIE
dialogues.text: This is amazing. This guy is Harry Nilsson.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Who the hell is Harry Nilsson?

dialogues.speaker: GEANNIE
dialogues.text: Lime in the coconut, she drank ‘em both up. Lime in the coconut.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Agh. I hate that song.

dialogues.speaker: GEANNIE
dialogues.text: This guy looks just like him.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Thanks. Really, I mean it. That might have just made my night. Luke walks on and sees Brie, back with Dickie. He walks over to them.  77.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, I think I’m gonna take off. Brie looks at him funny. Dickie extends his hand out.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: Cool man, it was great meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah. You too.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: I’ll keep an eye out for your stuff in the L.A. Times.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: Wait, do you have any interest in like, narrative stuff? Any fiction?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: Me and a bunch of people have this writing group. It’s just a bunch of jerks but you get some good feedback and a place to hear your stuff out loud. We’re always looking for more people. Would you be interested?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah, maybe actually.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: (to Dickie) How come you’ve never invited me into the writing group?

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: Haven't I? You can join. We need some more females in there.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: What do you have to do?

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: Just write something and send it to everyone and then they read it and talk about it at the meeting.  35 78.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Sounds intimidating.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: It’s chill. It’s usually at my house and my roommate makes these badass sugar cookies.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I like sugar cookies.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: Seriously, I’m sure you’d fit right in.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Cool. Brie’s got my number. Luke leans towards the door overexaggerating his gesture leave hoping Brie will call him back. She bites.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: (to Luke) I’m gonna have one more cigarette. Do you want one?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: Those give you cancer you know?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: So do sugar cookies.

dialogues.speaker: DICKIE
dialogues.text: Harsh. Brie gives him a wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke and Brie come back to the spot where they had their fight. Luke is carrying two beers for them and Brie is grabbing cigarettes out of her purse. She hands him a cigarette and lights her own. She lights for him and he hand her a beer. They both exhale a drag in silence.  79.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Listen, I’m sorry if I said something dumb before.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: No, I’m sorry too. I didn’t mean to run you off. Just a sore subject I guess.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: No, I understand.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: (soft) Thanks. Brie extends her bottle to Luke and he CLANKS his against BRIE (CONT’D) Cheers. They sip their drinks and smoke their cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Did I tell you I can play mouth trumpet?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Oh God. Let’s hear it. What songs do you play? What’s your repertoire? All Iron Maiden?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: For real? You wanna hear it?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Do you have any requests?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: You're just stalling.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Okay okay, hold on. Luke licks his lips. “Prepares.” Then he blows his way through the trumpet melody of “The Light” by Rand and Holland. Complete with pauses where the other instruments would be filling in the gaps. He finishes and shoots her a slightly impudent look.  80.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: That’s not half as bad as I thought it would be.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Thank you. I also do a mean mouth bass.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Upright or electric?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: It comes off mostly as upright.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Swell. Luke inspects his beer.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I think we drank a lot. Brie edges away. Looks up and around. Whatever spell the of them might have been under is broken.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I gotta go. I’ve gotta work tomorrow. Luke grimaces. He didn’t want to end the night on “mouth trumpet”.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Work is for suckers. Brie stands up. Luke follows.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Somebody’s got to hold that building up. They begin walking towards the front.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Should we say bye to Cameron?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: I doubt she’s coherent. Cameron stands in the doorway that they pass on their way out.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: HEY! Luke! Right? Luke?  81.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: There’s something I was supposed to ask you.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: The answer is yes. And it was magical. Cameron laughs. Who knows why.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Bye babe. We’re taking off.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Bye. Thanks for coming.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Nice meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: You too. It was magical.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: (points to her) Magical. Luke and Brie finally exit to the front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke and Brie walk down the dark street with the sounds o the party fading behind them. Luke walks slowly, defeated by the pressure surrounding t next few moments. Brie seems cool as a cucumber.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Cameron really likes you. Luke smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: She’s got good taste.  82.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: My God. You are cocky when you’re drunk.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Maybe I see myself through beer goggles.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Did you park close by?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I think so. I’m down... (looks around, locates himself) that street. But I’1ll walk you to your car.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Unless it’s further away than mine.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Ruthless.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Pragmatic. They walk in mostly silence, taking in the night.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you gonna be okay to drive?

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I don’t live far.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Okay. They reach Brie’s car and she pauses for a moment by her door. This is the moment.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE, (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: Okay, Lazy Bones Jones. She unlocks the doors and moves some shit off the passeng seat for him to sit.  83. 37 INT. BRIE’S CAR- CONTINUOUS 37 Luke sits in the passenger seat as Brie gets situated and drives slowly down the street.

dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.text: Alexander.

dialogues.text: Yeah, you can pull over. It’s the Accord there. Yeah, that bad boy right there.

dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.text: No. I woke up one morning and there it was.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: A late night dent and run?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: It was. The mystery remains unsolved...

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Yeah... Luke takes off his seatbelt and looks at Brie.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Well.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Thanks for driving me to my car.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: And thanks for hanging out, it was fun.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: It was. This is the moment. Luke nods and opens his door.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: See you later.

dialogues.speaker: BRIE
dialogues.text: Bye. Luke begins to get out of the car but freezes midway thro He looks back to see Brie watching him leave. He’s sudden feeling an urge to kiss her but he’s frozen in an awkward hover. Just to end it, he climbs fully out of the car and closes the door behind him. He puts his hand up as one last parting shot and she salu him back. And then she drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke watches her car while he unlocks the door to his own He opens the door and gets inside. INT. LUKE’S CAR- CONTINUOUS 39 Luke sits in the driver seat, staring ahead.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: You sir, are an idiot. You fuck. He quickly punches the ceiling of the car and quickly reg it.  40 86. He reaches into the glove compartment and pulls out his glasses and puts them on. He turns the key in the ignition and turns on the radio. After maybe five beats of the song, he turns it right bac off and reaches into his pocket. He pulls out his phone and dials a number. After two rings, Brie picks up.

dialogues.text: Cool. LUKE (CONT’D) Well, I’m kind of notorious for missing golden opportunities and maybe I’m crazy but I think that you wanted me to kiss you back there. Am I stupid or did I miss a golden opportunity?

After a moment, Brie’s car turns the corner at the other of the street and pulls over. Luke walks briskly to where she is. He gets to her car, opens the door and gets in. INT. BRIE’S CAR- CONTINUOUS 42 Before either has a chance to say anything, they embrace long, drunk kiss. Luke pulls away and clears his throat a little.

dialogues.text: Sorry about the unconventional. .. Brie takes off his glasses and tosses them in the back se  43 44 88.
